narration: Long, long ago, the world was created and watched over by a great god named Bathala. He was a kind and powerful ruler.
Bathala had two children whom he loved more than anything: a son named Apolaqui and a daughter named Mayari.
From their radiant eyes, the very first light shone upon the earth.
The people, the birds in the sky, and the fish in the sea rejoiced in this beautiful light.
Bathala loved his children so dearly that he never wanted to be apart from them and followed them day and night on their journeys.
But as time passed he grew old and weak. He asked them to stay by his side, but they were busy with adventures and did not listen.

quiz.question: Did Apolaqui and Mayari stay close when Bathala asked?

narration: One day, Bathala grew very ill and passed away suddenly, leaving no will about who should rule.
This caused a great argument between brother and sister.
Apolaqui wanted to rule the earth all by himself with no power for Mayari. She refused this unfair plan.

options.text: They disagreed about ruling the earth
They wanted to explore the sky
They were just playing a game

narration: Their relationship became unbalanced and turned into a terrible fight with bamboo clubs.
For a long time they battled. During the struggle Apolaqui's club struck Mayari’s face and she lost one of her beautiful, light-giving eyes.

quiz.question: What happened to Mayari during the fight?

options.text: She lost one of her eyes

narration: Seeing what he had done, Apolaqui was filled with regret and stopped fighting.
They made a peace agreement to share power over the earth equally at different times.
Apolaqui became the ruler of the Sun, shining bright with two eyes by day.
Mayari became the ruler of the Moon. Her gentle, silvery light is softer for she has but one eye—a reminder of their fight and the peace they found.

quiz.question: Why is Mayari’s light softer than Apolaqui’s?

narration: Moral: Power shared with fairness brings peace; regret can lead to healing; and even a loss can shine as a gentle reminder to choose harmony.
